pullRequest.body:
---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

### PR summary [382c476e2d](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/21134/commits/382c476e2dae9167765532c0fc8c4339f120393c)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ IsClosed.inter_preimage_val_iff`
`+ IsClosed.preimage_val`
`+ IsOpen.inter_preimage_val_iff`
`+ IsOpen.preimage_val`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

Thanks!
maintainer merge
ðŸš€ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by grunweg.

> I also think it is good to bear in mind Anatole's point: usually you want to prove things about any preimage, not just preimage under inclusion of a subset.

Yes, thank you both! I will keep this in mind. One question: I assumed that since this has its own notation (which does not really resemble a preimage) it should get its own lemmas. Is the reason for this not being the case that this is not global notation?

:v: scholzhannah can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/13503146420/job/37726365256)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/13503146420/job/37726364738)
Looks pretty good. Two quick comments.

As a general rule of thumb, most results about `s â†“âˆ© t` should be more general results about preimages. This serves both as an indication to look for such lemmas, and as a rule to write it down if it doesn't exist.

> One question: I assumed that since this has its own notation (which does not really resemble a preimage) it should get its own lemmas. Is the reason for this not being the case that this is not global notation?

This is a good question and I don't have a perfect answer but I can add some remarks.

What we like is to avoid repeating ourselves. Avoiding repetition reduces the surface area for inconsistencies (e.g., of style) and reduces our maintenance burden. Thus we like very general lemmas which apply in many situations. Notation should not affect the lemmas we write.

As to why this is not a global notation: I think it's for no better reason than we are quite conservative about anything global.

Thanks for this work!

bors d+
Looks pretty good. Two quick comments.

As a general rule of thumb, most results about `s â†“âˆ© t` should be more general results about preimages. This serves both as an indication to look for such lemmas, and as a rule to write it down if it doesn't exist.

Thanks for this. I have some minor suggestions.

I also think it is good to bear in mind Anatole's point: usually you want to prove things about any preimage, not just preimage under inclusion of a subset.

Still, these lemmas looks useful :)

> One question: I assumed that since this has its own notation (which does not really resemble a preimage) it should get its own lemmas. Is the reason for this not being the case that this is not global notation?

This is a good question and I don't have a perfect answer but I can add some remarks.

What we like is to avoid repeating ourselves. Avoiding repetition reduces the surface area for inconsistencies (e.g., of style) and reduces our maintenance burden. Thus we like very general lemmas which apply in many situations. Notation should not affect the lemmas we write.

As to why this is not a global notation: I think it's for no better reason than we are quite conservative about anything global.

Thanks for this work!

bors d+
Is there a reason you didn't call this `IsClosed.inter_of_isClosed_perimage_val`? Same for the previous lemma.
This is almost the same proof again. Do you see a way to unify these? (If not, we can merge it.)

```suggestion
lemma IsClosed.preimage_val {s t : Set X} (ht : IsClosed t) : IsClosed (s â†“âˆ© t) := 
  ht.preimage continuous_subtype_val
```

I'm tempted to suggest the same for the lemma above: morally this is just continuity of the inclusion.

```suggestion
  simpa using hs.isOpenMap_subtype_val hst
```
(untested)
(And same below)

I think we should prove both directions:
```suggestion
lemma IsOpen.inter_preimage_val_iff {s t : Set X} (hs : IsOpen s) :
    IsOpen (s â†“âˆ© t) â†” IsOpen (s âˆ© t) := by
```
Again both directions

Given that we keep opening the same notation:
```suggestion
section SetNotation

open scoped Set.Notation

```
(and close it below)

```suggestion
@[simp] lemma IsOpen.inter_preimage_val_iff {s t : Set X} (hs : IsOpen s) :
```

```suggestion
@[simp] lemma IsClosed.inter_preimage_val_iff {s t : Set X} (hs : IsClosed s) :
```

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: lemmas about openness and closedness under preimage of Subtype.val

I also think it is good to bear in mind Anatole's point: usually you want to prove things about any preimage, not just preimage under inclusion of a subset.

Still, these lemmas looks useful :)

> I also think it is good to bear in mind Anatole's point: usually you want to prove things about any preimage, not just preimage under inclusion of a subset.

Yes, thank you both! I will keep this in mind. One question: I assumed that since this has its own notation (which does not really resemble a preimage) it should get its own lemmas. Is the reason for this not being the case that this is not global notation?

> One question: I assumed that since this has its own notation (which does not really resemble a preimage) it should get its own lemmas. Is the reason for this not being the case that this is not global notation?

This is a good question and I don't have a perfect answer but I can add some remarks.

What we like is to avoid repeating ourselves. Avoiding repetition reduces the surface area for inconsistencies (e.g., of style) and reduces our maintenance burden. Thus we like very general lemmas which apply in many situations. Notation should not affect the lemmas we write.

As to why this is not a global notation: I think it's for no better reason than we are quite conservative about anything global.

Thanks for this work!
